elements.content: A novel two-dimensional dysprosium­(III) complex, [Dy­(L)­(CH3COO)]·0.5DMF·H2O·2CH3OH (1), has been successfully synthesized from a new pyridine-N-oxide (PNO)-containing ligand, namely, N′-(2-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzylidene)­pyridine-N-oxidecarbohydrazide (H2L). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that complex 1 is composed of a dinuclear dysprosium subunit, which is further extended by the PNO part of the ligand to form a two-dimensional layer. Magnetic studies indicate that complex 1 shows well-defined temperature- and frequency-dependent signals under a zero direct-current (dc) field, typical of slow magnetic relaxation with an effective energy barrier U eff of 33.6 K under a zero dc field. Interestingly, powder X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analysis reveal that compound 1 undergoes a reversible phase transition that is induced by the desorption and absorption of methanol and water molecules. Moreover, the desolvated sample [Dy­(L)­(CH3COO)]·0.5DMF (1a) also exhibits slow magnetic relaxation but with a higher anisotropic barrier of 42.0 K, indicating the tuning effect of solvent molecules on slow magnetic relaxation.

elements.content: A novel two-dimensional dysprosium complex possessing guest-dependent magnetic behavior has been synthesized from a new pyridine-N-oxide-containing ligand, which has been confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analysis. Both this complex and its desolvated phase show slow magnetic relaxation behavior under a zero direct-current field with effective energy barriers of 33.6 and 42.0 K, respectively.

Both this complex and its desolvated phase show slow magnetic relaxation behavior under a zero direct-current field with effective energy barriers of 33.6 and 42.0 K, respectively.

elements.content: In the past 2 decades, molecular nanomagnets have attracted extensive attention because they are considered to be promising candidates for future devices. In particular, studies of molecular nanomagnets have brought about an intriguing transitional regime between the fields of paramagnetism and bulk magnetism. Moreover, the unique structural characteristics of molecular nanomagnets allow the possibility of retaining the magnetic moment in a low-dimensional structure. Many elegant examples of molecular nanomagnets featuring slow magnetic relaxation and magnetic hysteresis at low temperatures have been documented. Also, it is well-known that the magnetic anisotropy of metal ions plays a crucial role in constructing molecular nanomagnets. In this regard, lanthanide ions such as terbium, dysprosium, holmium, and erbium ions are ideally suitable for the construction of high-performance molecular nanomagnets by virtue of their inherently large, unquenched orbital angular momentum and strong spin–orbit coupling, which may bring significant anisotropy to the system. Additionally, the characteristics of high coordination numbers and flexible coordination geometries of lanthanide ions can provide various intriguing structures. To date, a variety of lanthanide molecular nanomagnets have been documented, which include mononuclear, dinuclear, and polynuclear units, one-dimensional (1D) chains, two-dimensional (2D) layers, and three-dimensional (3D) structures. It is also worth noting that lanthanide-based molecular nanomagnets are known for possessing the highest relaxation energy barriers and the highest blocking temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past 2 decades, molecular nanomagnets have attracted extensive attention because they are considered to be promising candidates for future devices. In particular, studies of molecular nanomagnets have brought about an intriguing transitional regime between the fields of paramagnetism and bulk magnetism. Moreover, the unique structural characteristics of molecular nanomagnets allow the possibility of retaining the magnetic moment in a low-dimensional structure. Many elegant examples of molecular nanomagnets featuring slow magnetic relaxation and magnetic hysteresis at low temperatures have been documented. Also, it is well-known that the magnetic anisotropy of metal ions plays a crucial role in constructing molecular nanomagnets. In this regard, lanthanide ions such as terbium, dysprosium, holmium, and erbium ions are ideally suitable for the construction of high-performance molecular nanomagnets by virtue of their inherently large, unquenched orbital angular momentum and strong spin-orbit coupling, which may bring significant anisotropy to the system. Additionally, the characteristics of high coordination numbers and flexible coordination geometries of lanthanide ions can provide various intriguing structures. To date, a variety of lanthanide molecular nanomagnets have been documented, which include mononuclear, dinuclear, and polynuclear units, one-dimensional (1D) chains, two-dimensional (2D) layers, and three-dimensional (3D) structures. It is also worth noting that lanthanide-based molecular nanomagnets are known for possessing the highest relaxation energy barriers and the highest blocking temperature.

elements.content: It is well-known that many factors can influence the behavior of lanthanide molecular nanomagnets. For example, the type of lanthanide ions and ligand, the coordination number and coordination geometry of lanthanide ions, and the magnetic interactions between lanthanide ions are all important parameters to consider. Thus, the selection of the appropriate ligand with bridging and terminal groups plays the most crucial role in synthesizing novel molecular nanomagnets. In the reported papers, pyridine carbohydrazine based Schiff-base ligands have been successfully employed to direct the formation of several structurally and magnetically fascinating dysprosium nanomagnets, in large part because these types of ligands can supply a strong coordination field and provide oxygen–nitrogen–oxygen-based multichelating sites to form a coordinated pocket that accommodates lanthanide ions. While a series of zero-dimensional lanthanide molecular nanomagnets have been successfully constructed from pyridine carbohydrazine based Schiff-base ligands; multidimensional complexes constructed by these ligands are relatively rare because of the conceivably weak coordination capabilities between pyridine nitrogen atoms and lanthanide ions. Recently, our group demonstrated that the employment of a pyridine-N-oxide (PNO) group instead of a pyridine one can significantly increase the ligand’s coordination capabilities with lanthanide ions, and a novel 1D dysprosium system that featured slow magnetic relaxation with relatively high energy barriers of 227 K under a zero direct-current (dc) field was successfully constructed. We wondered whether altering the position of the PNO group and providing different types of multichelating aldehydes could synthesize multidimensional (2D and 3D) and functionally more useful lanthanide systems with slow magnetic relaxation. We anticipate that such higher-dimensional systems may benefit the ordered arrangement of the Ising-axis direction in multidimensions and produce novel magnetic phenomena. Moreover, we envisage that this concept can provide a possible platform to fabricate multifunctional porous magnetic materials, which may potentially be incorporated with open channels that allow the insertion and/or removal of guest molecules.

elements.content: The insertion and/or removal of guest molecules may change the bond lengths and angles, coordination geometry, or coordination packing of the compounds, causing different intramolecular and/or intermolecular interactions. Subtle structural differences can lead to distinct magnetic properties, producing guest-dependent magnetic behavior. Up to now, many guest-dependent magnetic materials have been reported, including antiferromagnet-to-ferromagnet, ferrimagnet-to-ferromagnet, and single-chain-magnet-to-metamagnet transitions, guest-dependent magnetization and magnetic ordering temperature, and a high spin to low spin transition. Although many transition-metal systems with guest-dependent magnetic properties have been documented in the literature, the combination of slow magnetic relaxation of the lanthanide system with guest adsorption and desorption behavior is still a challenge because it is more difficult to construct a lanthanide system with porous structure compared to its transition-metal counterpart. In this context, we describe an intriguing 2D dysprosium compound, which can be formulated as [Dy­(L)­(CH3COO)]·0.5DMF·H2O·2CH3OH (1), in which slow magnetic relaxation under a zero dc field and antiferromagnetic interaction between the Dy3+ ions are found. Interestingly, the slow magnetic relaxation process can be tuned by the desorption of methanol (CH3OH) and water guest molecules, which can be further evidenced by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The desolvated sample [Dy­(L)­(CH3COO)]·0.5DMF (1a) also shows slow magnetic relaxation behavior under a zero dc field with a slightly larger energy barrier (42.0 K) and a stronger quantum tunnelling effect at low temperatures.

Experimental Section

The ligand of N'-(2-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzylidene)pyridine-N-oxidecarbohydrazide (H2L; ) was synthesized according to literature procedures. Other reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and were used as received without further purification.

elements.content: H2L (0.05 mmol, 0.0143 g) was dissolved in a mixture solvent of methanol (CH3OH; 1 mL) and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF; 0.75 mL). A methanolic solution of sodium hydroxide (NaOH; 1 mL, 50 mmol L–1) was then added to the mixture, affording a red solution. After stirring for 5 min, Dy­(OOCCH3)3·4H2O (0.05 mmol, 0.0206 g) was added, upon which the color of the solution immediately changed to yellow. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for another 10 min. After filtration, the filtrate was transferred to a test tube and layered with 2 mL of CH3OH. Block yellow crystals appeared in 1 week. Yield: 23.4 mg (74.6% based on the metal salt). Elem anal. Calcd for DyC19.5H27.5N3.5O9.5: C, 37.45; N, 7.84; H, 4.43. Found: C, 37.45; N, 7.89; H, 4.42. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3421­(br), 1674(s), 1608(s), 1562(s), 1525(s), 1454(s), 1359­(m), 1217(s), 1078­(m), 960­(m), 744(s).

elements.content:
Compound 1a was immersed in a mixture solvent of water, CH3OH, and DMF for 48 h and then filtered, and compound 1″ was obtained.

Results and DiscussionCrystal Structure of <bold>1</bold>

1 was obtained by the reaction of H2L with Dy­(OAc)3·4H2O in a 4:3 (v/v) CH3OH/DMF solution in the presence of NaOH, followed by slow diffusion of CH3OH. Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/n space group and displays an interesting 2D layer structure sustained by the PNO part of ligand H2L (). Details of the crystal parameters together with the structural refinement of 1 are listed in Table S1, and selected bond lengths are given in Table S2. The asymmetric unit of 1 is composed of one Dy3+ ion, one L2– ligand, one CH3COO– ion, a half uncoordinated DMF molecule, one lattice water molecule, and two lattice CH3OH molecules. Each Dy3+ ion is eight-coordinated by one PNO oxygen atom (O1), one carbonyl oxygen atom (O2), two phenoxide oxygen atoms (O3), one methoxide oxygen atom (O4), two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O5 and O6), and one imine nitrogen atom (N3), forming a hula-hoop-like coordination geometry (b). The Dy–O distances are in the range of 2.322–2.449 Å. The coordination geometry and bond length around Dy3+ ions are similar to those in other reported dysprosium-containing complexes. Two L2– ligands coordinate two Dy3+ ions in an antiparallel fashion, with the tridentate part (O1, N3, and O2) and the bidentate o-vanillin group (O2a and O3) forming a dinuclear subunit. Within the dinuclear subunit, two Dy3+ ions are bridged by two phenoxide μ-oxygen atoms from two ligands with Dy–O bond lengths of 2.328 and 2.403 Å, a Dy···Dy distance of 3.648 Å, and a Dy–O–Dy angle of 100.9° (a). The dihedral angle between the Dy2O2 plane and the benzene ring has a small value of 13.29°, indicating an almost coplanar configuration between them. Previous studies have reported three dinuclear and one 2D dysprosium complexes based on carbohydrazine Schiff-base ligands, in which two dysprosium ions are bridged by phenoxide oxygen atoms. Among these four dysprosium complexes, the Dy2O2 plane and the benzene ring are all nearly in the same plane and the bond lengths of Dy–Ophenoxide are similar to each other, falling in the range of 2.311–2.401 Å, while the angle of Dy–O–Dy is drastically different. Two of these known compounds have quite large Dy–O–Dy angles of 106.4° and 107.7° and display pronounced ferromagnetic interactions, whereas the other two show relatively smaller Dy–O–Dy angles of 100.1° and 104.3° and exhibit antiferromagnetic interactions between Dy3+ ions. Therefore, we surmise that the angle of Dy–O–Dy may have a great influence on the magnetic interactions between Dy3+ ions. Two carboxylate groups adopt the syn–syn bridging mode, further connecting adjacent Dy3+ ions within the dinuclear core, which is not observed in previously reported dinuclear dysprosium carbohydrazine complexes. Notably, similar to our previously published 1D chain compound, the PNO part of L2– coordinates to the Dy3+ ions of a neighboring dinuclear subunit, resulting in a 2D (4,4) layer structure based on Dy2 units (c). Thus, complex 1 is a rare example of a 2D layer complex containing dinuclear dysprosium subunits based on the pyridine-N-oxidecarbohydrazine Schiff-base ligand, in which the dinuclear core is connected by phenolate oxygen atoms and acetate groups via the syn–syn bridging mode. The network topology of 1 is similar to that of another 2D Dy3+-containing compound with slow magnetic relaxation reported by Yamashita et al.; however, the linkages within and between the dimer units are quite different. In the reported compound, within the Dy2 dimer, the nine-coordinated Dy3+ ions are bridged by μ3-η1:η2 carboxylate groups and the dimer units are further connected by a photosensitive carboxylate ligand to form a 2D layer structure. The adjacent layers are further linked by weak intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions between amide nitrogen atoms and a hydrogen atom of the benzene ring (C11–H11A···N2, C11···N2 = 3.303 Å, ∠C11–H11A···N3 = 138.75°), producing a complicated 3D framework (Figure S1).

Crystal Structure of 1

Details of the crystal parameters together with the structural refinement of 1 are listed in Table S1, and selected bond lengths are given in Table S2. The asymmetric unit of 1 is composed of one Dy3+ ion, one L2- ligand, one CH3COO- ion, a half uncoordinated DMF molecule, one lattice water molecule, and two lattice CH3OH molecules. Each Dy3+ ion is eight-coordinated by one PNO oxygen atom (O1), one carbonyl oxygen atom (O2), two phenoxide oxygen atoms (O3), one methoxide oxygen atom (O4), two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O5 and O6), and one imine nitrogen atom (N3), forming a hula-hoop-like coordination geometry (b). Two L2- ligands coordinate two Dy3+ ions in an antiparallel fashion, with the tridentate part (O1, N3, and O2) and the bidentate o-vanillin group (O2a and O3) forming a dinuclear subunit. Within the dinuclear subunit, two Dy3+ ions are bridged by two phenoxide μ-oxygen atoms from two ligands with Dy-O bond lengths of 2.328 and 2.403 Å, a Dy⋅⋅⋅Dy distance of 3.648 Å, and a Dy-O-Dy angle of 100.9° (a). The dihedral angle between the Dy2O2 plane and the benzene ring has a small value of 13.29°, indicating an almost coplanar configuration between them. Previous studies have reported three dinuclear and one 2D dysprosium complexes based on carbohydrazine Schiff-base ligands, in which two dysprosium ions are bridged by phenoxide oxygen atoms. Two carboxylate groups adopt the syn-syn bridging mode, further connecting adjacent Dy3+ ions within the dinuclear core, which is not observed in previously reported dinuclear dysprosium carbohydrazine complexes. Notably, similar to our previously published 1D chain compound, the PNO part of L2- coordinates to the Dy3+ ions of a neighboring dinuclear subunit, resulting in a 2D (4,4) layer structure based on Dy2 units (c). Thus, complex 1 is a rare example of a 2D layer complex containing dinuclear dysprosium subunits based on the pyridine-N-oxidecarbohydrazine Schiff-base ligand, in which the dinuclear core is connected by phenolate oxygen atoms and acetate groups via the syn-syn bridging mode. The network topology of 1 is similar to that of another 2D Dy3+-containing compound with slow magnetic relaxation reported by Yamashita et al.; however, the linkages within and between the dimer units are quite different. In the reported compound, within the Dy2 dimer, the nine-coordinated Dy3+ ions are bridged by μ3-η1:η2 carboxylate groups and the dimer units are further connected by a photosensitive carboxylate ligand to form a 2D layer structure. The adjacent layers are further linked by weak intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions between amide nitrogen atoms and a hydrogen atom of the benzene ring (C11-H11A⋅⋅⋅N2, C11⋅⋅⋅N2 = 3.303 Å, ∠C11-H11A⋅⋅⋅N3 = 138.75°), producing a complicated 3D framework (Figure S1).

elements.content: In order to confirm the phase purity of 1, we measured the powder X-ray diffraction data (PXRD) of the microcrystalline sample used for magnetic measurement at room temperature (Figure S2). The diffraction peaks of the as-prepared samples are in conformity with the corresponding simulated pattern calculated from single-crystal data, demonstrating high phase purity of complex 1.
elements.clean_text: In order to confirm the phase purity of 1, we measured the powder X-ray diffraction data (PXRD) of the microcrystalline sample used for magnetic measurement at room temperature (Figure S2). The diffraction peaks of the as-prepared samples are in conformity with the corresponding simulated pattern calculated from single-crystal data, demonstrating high phase purity of complex 1.

elements.content: dc magnetic susceptibility measurements have been performed on microcrystalline samples of 1 in the temperature range of 2–300 K at 1 kOe. As shown in , at room temperature, the observed χM T value of 29.04 cm3 mol–1 K is slightly larger than the expected value (28.34 cm3 mol–1 K) for two uncoupled Dy3+ ions with the ground state 6H15/2 and g = 4/3. The χM T value gradually decreases with a lowering of the temperature from 300 to 80 K, after which it decreases even more rapidly to reach 5.39 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. Thermal evolution of the magnetic susceptibility of 1 may be ascribed to the progressive depopulation of the excited-state m J sublevels of Dy3+ ions and/or the very strong antiferromagnetic interactions between Dy3+ ions within the dinuclear core. The field dependence of magnetization of 1 was investigated in the range of 0–50 kOe at 2, 3, 5, 8, and 10 K, respectively (). A rapid increase of the magnetization is observed at low magnetic fields, followed by a linear increase to 13.1 Nβ at 2 K. The nonsaturation of magnetization at 50 kOe and the nonsuperposition of the M versus H/T plots suggest the presence of a significant magnetic anisotropy and/or low-lying excited states in 1.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Behavior of 1 

dc magnetic susceptibility measurements have been performed on microcrystalline samples of 1 in the temperature range of 2-300 K at 1 kOe. As shown in , at room temperature, the observed χM T value of 29.04 cm3 mol-1 K is slightly larger than the expected value (28.34 cm3 mol-1 K) for two uncoupled Dy3+ ions with the ground state 6H15/2 and g = 4/3. The χM T value gradually decreases with a lowering of the temperature from 300 to 80 K, after which it decreases even more rapidly to reach 5.39 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. Thermal evolution of the magnetic susceptibility of 1 may be ascribed to the progressive depopulation of the excited-state m  J  sublevels of Dy3+ ions and/or the very strong antiferromagnetic interactions between Dy3+ ions within the dinuclear core. The field dependence of magnetization of 1 was investigated in the range of 0-50 kOe at 2, 3, 5, 8, and 10 K, respectively (). A rapid increase of the magnetization is observed at low magnetic fields, followed by a linear increase to 13.1 Nβ at 2 K. The nonsaturation of magnetization at 50 kOe and the nonsuperposition of the M versus H/T plots suggest the presence of a significant magnetic anisotropy and/or low-lying excited states in 1.

elements.content: In order to gain more insight on the magnetic anisotropy and interactions between the Dy3+ ions, CASSCF/RASSI calculations on individual dysprosium fragments of complex 1 on the basis of the geometries determined by XRD analysis have been carried out using the MOLCAS 7.8 and SINGLE_ANISO programs. The results provide the lowest spin–orbit energies and the corresponding g tensors of one dysprosium fragment extracted from complex 1. From Table S4, we can see that the energy separation between the ground and first excited doublet states for the Dy3+ fragments is 63.4 cm–1 and the effective g tensor of the ground Kramers doublet on the dysprosium sites is strongly axial (g x = 0.042, g y = 0.089, and g z = 18.921). Therefore, Dy3+–Dy3+ exchange interaction can be approximately regarded as the Ising type. The main magnetic axes on two dysprosium ions are indicated in , where the magnetic axes on two dysprosium ions are antiparallel to each other because of the Dy3+–Dy3+ antiferromagnetic interaction. Experimental magnetic susceptibility of complex 1 is further simulated with the program POLY_ANISO using the exchange parameters from Table S3. The calculated and experimental χM T versus T plots of complex 1 are shown in , where the calculated data are reasonably consistent with the experimental data in the entire temperature range, indicating the validity of the ab initio calculations. The broken-symmetry density functional theory (BS-DFT) method has been used to calculate the Dy3+–Dy3+ exchange interactions (see the Supporting Information for computational details). Also, the Lines model has also been employed to fit the Dy3+–Dy3+ interactions. Both the calculation result using the BS-DFT method and the fitting result using the Lines model demonstrate that the overall Dy3+–Dy3+ coupling constant is negative (Table S3), confirming obvious antiferromagnetic interactions between Dy3+ ions within the dinuclear core. As discussed above, the obvious antiferromagnetic interaction between Dy3+ ions is probably related to the relatively small Dy–O–Dy angles within the dinuclear core and/or the small dihedral angle between the Dy2O2 plane and the benzene ring.
elements.clean_text: In order to gain more insight on the magnetic anisotropy and interactions between the Dy3+ ions, CASSCF/RASSI calculations on individual dysprosium fragments of complex 1 on the basis of the geometries determined by XRD analysis have been carried out using the MOLCAS 7.8  and SINGLE_ANISO  programs. The results provide the lowest spin-orbit energies and the corresponding g tensors of one dysprosium fragment extracted from complex 1. From Table S4, we can see that the energy separation between the ground and first excited doublet states for the Dy3+ fragments is 63.4 cm-1 and the effective g tensor of the ground Kramers doublet on the dysprosium sites is strongly axial (g  x  = 0.042, g  y  = 0.089, and g  z  = 18.921). Therefore, Dy3+-Dy3+ exchange interaction can be approximately regarded as the Ising type. The main magnetic axes on two dysprosium ions are indicated in , where the magnetic axes on two dysprosium ions are antiparallel to each other because of the Dy3+-Dy3+ antiferromagnetic interaction. Experimental magnetic susceptibility of complex 1 is further simulated with the program POLY_ANISO  using the exchange parameters from Table S3. The calculated and experimental χM T versus T plots of complex 1 are shown in , where the calculated data are reasonably consistent with the experimental data in the entire temperature range, indicating the validity of the ab initio calculations. The broken-symmetry density functional theory (BS-DFT) method has been used to calculate the Dy3+-Dy3+ exchange interactions (see the Supporting Information for computational details). Also, the Lines model has also been employed to fit the Dy3+-Dy3+ interactions. Both the calculation result using the BS-DFT method and the fitting result using the Lines model demonstrate that the overall Dy3+-Dy3+ coupling constant is negative (Table S3), confirming obvious antiferromagnetic interactions between Dy3+ ions within the dinuclear core. As discussed above, the obvious antiferromagnetic interaction between Dy3+ ions is probably related to the relatively small Dy-O-Dy angles within the dinuclear core and/or the small dihedral angle between the Dy2O2 plane and the benzene ring.

elements.content: To further explore the dynamics of magnetization, alternating-current (ac) susceptibility measurements were performed for 1 under a zero dc field. As shown in , the peaks in the temperature-dependent ac susceptibility are quite distorted with a shoulder structure. The shift of the χM″ peaks exhibits a strong frequency dependence as the temperature decreases, showing prominent slow magnetic relaxation expected for molecular nanomagnets. To quantify its slow relaxation, the relaxation time was extracted from the frequency-dependent data between 2 and 8 K and Arrhenius plots were constructed to investigate the temperature-dependent magnetic relaxation (Figure S3 and Table S5 and ). At lower temperatures (T < 3.5 K), the dynamics of 1 become nearly temperature-independent as expected in a pure quantum regime with an average τ value of 0.172 ms. Between 3.5 and 5.25 K, the quantum tunnelling mechanism is gradually replaced by thermal relaxation. Above 5.5 K, the relaxation time exhibits an exponential dependence on the reciprocal of temperature, and the Arrhenius fitting on the data affords an anisotropy energy barrier of 33.6 K with a preexponential factor (τ0) of 2.9 × 10–7 s (). This is consistent with the expected value for lanthanide superparamagnetic systems. The distribution of the relaxation processes was further investigated by Cole–Cole plots in the temperature range of 2–8 K (Figure S4). Attempted fits of the data using a generalized Debye model gave slightly large α parameters (0.12–0.21), suggesting that there is mainly one single relaxation process involved in 1.

elements.content: To suppress the quantum tunnelling process below 5.5 K, ac susceptibility measurements were conducted at various frequencies under an optimum dc field of 3 kOe. As shown in Figure S6, the shoulder structure originally present in the temperature-dependent ac susceptibility data under a zero dc field disappeared and the shape of χac–T plots became typical, as seen for most lanthanide molecular nanomagnets. Substantial peaks of χM′ and χM″ can be found for all frequencies used, and the tail of χM′ and χM″ decreases notably below 4 K, indicating the reduction of the quantum tunnelling of magnetization (QTM) in a static dc field. Moreover, the peak maximum temperature of χM″ slightly shifts from 7.60 to 7.80 K at 10 kHz. Additionally, effective suppression of the quantum tunnelling under an optimum field of 3 kOe dc field can also be observed through ln τ versus T –1 plots, and the relaxation time at 2 K increases to 91.1 ms. Figure S8 shows the corresponding Arrhenius plot based on the ac–f data (Figure S7 and Table S6), affording U eff = 49.2 K and τ0 = 2.5 × 10–7 s, which are slightly higher than those observed under a zero dc field.

elements.content: To investigate the thermal stability of compound 1 and further affirm the exact molecular formula of the compound, TGA was performed in the temperature range of 35–800 °C under a synthetic air atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C min–1. The TGA curve of 1 exhibits three main steps of weight loss between room temperature and about 600 °C (Figure S9). The initial weight loss of 13.0% below 100 °C corresponds to the release of one interstitial water molecule as well as two CH3OH solvent molecules (calcd 13.1%). The weight loss of 5.9% in the temperature range of 100–180 °C stems from the release of one lattice DMF molecule (calcd 5.8%). Above 200 °C, the mass sharply decreases, which is assigned to thermal decomposition of the L2– ligand, leaving a residue of Dy2O3 with a final weight of 29.7% (calcd 29.8%).
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability and Reversibility of Dehydration of Compound 1 

To investigate the thermal stability of compound 1 and further affirm the exact molecular formula of the compound, TGA was performed in the temperature range of 35-800 °C under a synthetic air atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C min-1. The TGA curve of 1 exhibits three main steps of weight loss between room temperature and about 600 °C (Figure S9). The initial weight loss of 13.0% below 100 °C corresponds to the release of one interstitial water molecule as well as two CH3OH solvent molecules (calcd 13.1%). The weight loss of 5.9% in the temperature range of 100-180 °C stems from the release of one lattice DMF molecule (calcd 5.8%). Above 200 °C, the mass sharply decreases, which is assigned to thermal decomposition of the L2- ligand, leaving a residue of Dy2O3 with a final weight of 29.7% (calcd 29.8%).

elements.content: It is interesting to note that when we very gently heat the sample of 1 at 35 °C under vacuum for 6 h or expose it to air for 1 month at room temperature, a dehydrated phase with the formula of [Dy­(L)­(OOCCH3)]·0.5DMF (1a) can be obtained. The thermal stability of 1a was also explored by TGA analysis, which revealed no weight loss below 100 °C (i.e., the absence of CH3OH and water guest molecules) but two weight loss steps at higher temperatures (Figure S9). The first weight loss of 6.9% below 180 °C, consistent with the calculated value of 6.7%, corresponds to the release of half of an interstitial DMF molecule. The second weight loss occurs in the temperature range of 200–700 °C and can be attributed to decomposition of the L2– ligand, giving rise to a residue of Dy2O3 with a final weight of 34.1% (calcd 34.3%). In the XRD pattern of 1a, the peaks at around 10° shift to a higher 2θ range compared to those of the as-synthesized 1, and a new sharp peak appears at ca. 12°, indicating structural transformation to lower symmetry upon the release of water and CH3OH molecules ().

The thermal stability of 1a was also explored by TGA analysis, which revealed no weight loss below 100 °C (i.e., the absence of CH3OH and water guest molecules) but two weight loss steps at higher temperatures (Figure S9). The first weight loss of 6.9% below 180 °C, consistent with the calculated value of 6.7%, corresponds to the release of half of an interstitial DMF molecule. The second weight loss occurs in the temperature range of 200-700 °C and can be attributed to decomposition of the L2- ligand, giving rise to a residue of Dy2O3 with a final weight of 34.1% (calcd 34.3%). In the XRD pattern of 1a, the peaks at around 10° shift to a higher 2θ range compared to those of the as-synthesized 1, and a new sharp peak appears at ca. 12°, indicating structural transformation to lower symmetry upon the release of water and CH3OH molecules ().

elements.content: When compound 1a was immersed in a mixture solvent of water, CH3OH, and DMF for 48h, it reabsorbed the solvent molecules and was converted to the resolvated phase 1″. Both XRD and TGA studies revealed that the structure of 1″ was the same as that of 1 ( and S9). Most interestingly, the results indicated that 1a absorbed CH3OH and water molecules reversibly and converted back to the original phase 1 upon resolvation. The reversible structural transformation provides an opportunity to achieve reversible manipulation of magnetic behaviors and to fabricate multifunctional hybrid materials.

The reversible structural transformation provides an opportunity to achieve reversible manipulation of magnetic behaviors and to fabricate multifunctional hybrid materials.

elements.content: To fully understand the mechanism of reversible-phase transformation, we solved the solid-state structure of 1a using the software TOPAS4.2. The framework of 1a is similar to that of 1, in which the dinuclear subunit is also connected by the PNO part of the H2L ligand, forming a 2D layer structure (Figure S10). The coordinating atoms around the lanthanide ions of 1a are the same as those in 1, where each Dy3+ ion is also eight-coordinated in a hula-loop-like geometry (Figure S10b). However, the local Dy–O bond lengths of 1a are noticeably distinct from those in 1 (Table S2). In compound 1a, the Dy–O distances fall in the range of 2.213(5)–2.434(5) Å. The bond lengths of Dy–Ocarbonyl and Dy–Ophenolate in 1a are longer than the corresponding bond lengths in 1, the Dy–OOCH3 and Dy–OPNO bond distances in 1a are shorter than those of 1, and the Dy–N bond length remains nearly unchanged. The two Dy3+ ions within the dinuclear core are also connected by two phenoxide μ-oxygen atoms with a Dy···Dy distance of 3.710 Å and a Dy–O–Dy angle of 101.6°, similar to the corresponding values in compound 1. Noticeably, the dihedral angle between the Dy2O2 plane and the phenyl ring in 1a (42.57°) is drastically larger than the corresponding one in 1 (13.29°). The pronounced variations in the Dy–O distances and aforementioned dihedral angle compared to those in the fully solvated compound 1 likely play an important role in mediating magnetic interactions between Dy3+ ions within the dinuclear core and thus influencing the magnetic relaxation of compound 1a.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 1a 

To fully understand the mechanism of reversible-phase transformation, we solved the solid-state structure of 1a using the software TOPAS4.2. The framework of 1a is similar to that of 1, in which the dinuclear subunit is also connected by the PNO part of the H2L ligand, forming a 2D layer structure (Figure S10). The coordinating atoms around the lanthanide ions of 1a are the same as those in 1, where each Dy3+ ion is also eight-coordinated in a hula-loop-like geometry (Figure S10b). However, the local Dy-O bond lengths of 1a are noticeably distinct from those in 1 (Table S2). In compound 1a, the Dy-O distances fall in the range of 2.213(5)-2.434(5) Å. The bond lengths of Dy-Ocarbonyl and Dy-Ophenolate in 1a are longer than the corresponding bond lengths in 1, the Dy-OOCH3  and Dy-OPNO bond distances in 1a are shorter than those of 1, and the Dy-N bond length remains nearly unchanged. The two Dy3+ ions within the dinuclear core are also connected by two phenoxide μ-oxygen atoms with a Dy⋅⋅⋅Dy distance of 3.710 Å and a Dy-O-Dy angle of 101.6°, similar to the corresponding values in compound 1. Noticeably, the dihedral angle between the Dy2O2 plane and the phenyl ring in 1a (42.57°) is drastically larger than the corresponding one in 1 (13.29°). The pronounced variations in the Dy-O distances and aforementioned dihedral angle compared to those in the fully solvated compound 1 likely play an important role in mediating magnetic interactions between Dy3+ ions within the dinuclear core and thus influencing the magnetic relaxation of compound 1a.

elements.content: To study the effect of desolvation on the magnetic properties, we measured the magnetic susceptibility of 1a in the temperature range of 2–300 K. As shown in , the experimental χM T value of 27.81 cm3 mol–1 K obtained at room temperature is slightly smaller than the excepted value (28.34 cm3 mol–1 K) for two uncoupled dysprosium ions in the ground state 6H15/2 with g = 4/3. The χM T value decreases slowly upon a decrease in the temperature from 300 to 100 K, after which it decreases more rapidly to reach 10.24 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. Thermal evolution of the magnetic susceptibility of 1a is similar to that of 1, which is attributed to depopulation of the Stark sublevels and/or interdimer antiferromagnetic interactions. The lack of a superposition of the M–H/T data on a single master curve and the low magnetization of 12.10 Nβ also suggest the presence of a significant magnetic anisotropy and/or low-lying excited states ().
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Behavior of Complex 1a 

To study the effect of desolvation on the magnetic properties, we measured the magnetic susceptibility of 1a in the temperature range of 2-300 K. As shown in , the experimental χM T value of 27.81 cm3 mol-1 K obtained at room temperature is slightly smaller than the excepted value (28.34 cm3 mol-1 K) for two uncoupled dysprosium ions in the ground state 6H15/2 with g = 4/3. The χM T value decreases slowly upon a decrease in the temperature from 300 to 100 K, after which it decreases more rapidly to reach 10.24 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. Thermal evolution of the magnetic susceptibility of 1a is similar to that of 1, which is attributed to depopulation of the Stark sublevels and/or interdimer antiferromagnetic interactions. The lack of a superposition of the M-H/T data on a single master curve and the low magnetization of 12.10 Nβ also suggest the presence of a significant magnetic anisotropy and/or low-lying excited states ().

elements.content: CASSCF/RASSI calculations on individual dysprosium fragments of complex 1a on the basis of the geometries determined by XRD analysis have also been carried out using the MOLCAS 7.8 and SINGLE_ANISO programs. From Table S4, we can see that the calculated energy separation between the ground and the first excited doublet states for the Dy3+ fragments of 1a is 45.4 cm–1, which is smaller than that of 1 (63.4 cm–1), suggesting the effect of solvent molecules. In addition, the calculation results give the effective g tensor of the ground Kramers doublet of 1a: g x = 0.265, g y = 0.741, and g z = 18.970, indicating strong axiality of the Dy3+ ion. Also, Dy3+–Dy3+ exchange interaction can be approximately regarded as the Ising type. The magnetic susceptibility of complex 1a is further simulated with the program POLY_ANISO using the exchange parameters from Table S3. The calculated and experimental χM T versus T plots of complex 1a are shown in , where the calculated data are reasonably consistent with the experimental data in the entire temperature range. The main magnetic axes on two dysprosium ions of 1a are indicated in Figure S12, where the magnetic axes on two dysprosium ions are also antiparallel to each other, the direction of which is similar to that of 1. The BS-DFT method and Lines model have also been used to calculate and fit the Dy3+–Dy3+ exchange interactions, respectively. Both the calculation results using the BS-DFT method and fitting result using the Lines model demonstrate that the overall Dy3+–Dy3+ coupling constant is negative (Table S3), confirming the antiferromagnetic interactions between Dy3+ ions within the dinuclear core.

elements.content: Another interesting aspect of compound 1a is that it exhibits dynamic magnetic behavior drastically different from that of 1. As shown in , both the real (χM′) and imaginary (χM″) parts of the ac susceptibility show strong temperature and frequency dependence below 8 K. Slow relaxation of the magnetization signals is characteristic of molecular nanomagnets. Compared with compound 1, the tail value of χM′ and χM″ for 1a is noticeably higher, indicating that zero-field QTM may play a more dominant role below 4 K, presumably as a result of the change in the Dy–O distances upon the desolvation process. Moreover, at 10 kHz, χM″ of 1a shows a maximum value at around 4.80 K, which is significantly lower than the corresponding temperature (7.60 K) observed for 1 under otherwise identical conditions. In addition, the relaxation dynamics were studied by measuring the ac susceptibility as a function of the frequency (Figure S13 and Table S7). Fitting the ln τ versus 1/T data to the Arrhenius plot (), we obtained an anisotropy barrier of 42.0 K, which is higher than that of 1. The α value extracted from the generalized Debye model is in the range of 0.22–0.35, indicating that more than one relaxation pathway is likely involved at 2–7 K. Under an optimum dc field of 1 kOe, the low-temperature quantum tunnelling relaxation process can be partially suppressed, and the peak maximum temperature of 1a shifts from 4.80 to 6.00 K at 10 kHz (Figure S16). Figure S17 shows the corresponding Arrhenius plot derived from the ac data, and the high temperature nicely follows a thermally activated behavior with an effective energy barrier of U eff = 61.6 K, which is much higher than that of 1a under a zero dc field.

elements.content: Although many transition-metal systems show guest-dependent magnetic behavior, relatively little work has been reported on the pure lanthanide system with guest-dependent magnetic behavior. Recently, Cheng’s group reported a nice example where the exchange of guest molecules (DMF and CH3CN) induces modification of magnetic behaviors in a lanthanide-based metal–organic framework featuring Dy2 single-molecule magnets as nodes. Similar to this work, our system (complexes 1 and 1a) also demonstrates reversible desorption and adsorption behavior. However, in contrast to Cheng’s study, pronounced structural transformation and phase transition can be observed in compound 1 upon the release of CH3OH and water guest molecules. Specifically, the phase transition has led to a notable change of the coordination environment surrounding Dy3+ ions and of the connectivity between Dy3+ ions within the dinuclear core. More importantly, Cheng and co-workers contemplated that the guest-dependent relaxation rate of the incoherent QTM accounts for the distinct magnetic behaviors between the Dy2-DMF and Dy2-CH3CN phases; in contrast, the different magnetic behavior between 1 and 1a is mainly ascribed to the structural changes as a result of the release of guest molecules. Both the Dy–O distances and the dihedral angle between the Dy2O2 and phenyl planes changed greatly upon the loss of guest molecules, which further induces distinct magnetic relaxation behavior between 1 and 1a. To the best of our knowledge, complex 1 represents a rare example of the 2D dysprosium layer structure that possesses guest-dependent magnetic relaxation.
elements.clean_text:
Guest-Dependent Slow Magnetic Relaxation in 1 

Although many transition-metal systems show guest-dependent magnetic behavior, relatively little work has been reported on the pure lanthanide system with guest-dependent magnetic behavior. Recently, Cheng's group reported a nice example where the exchange of guest molecules (DMF and CH3CN) induces modification of magnetic behaviors in a lanthanide-based metal-organic framework featuring Dy2 single-molecule magnets as nodes. Similar to this work, our system (complexes 1 and 1a) also demonstrates reversible desorption and adsorption behavior. However, in contrast to Cheng's study, pronounced structural transformation and phase transition can be observed in compound 1 upon the release of CH3OH and water guest molecules. Specifically, the phase transition has led to a notable change of the coordination environment surrounding Dy3+ ions and of the connectivity between Dy3+ ions within the dinuclear core. More importantly, Cheng and co-workers contemplated that the guest-dependent relaxation rate of the incoherent QTM accounts for the distinct magnetic behaviors between the Dy2-DMF and Dy2-CH3CN phases; in contrast, the different magnetic behavior between 1 and 1a is mainly ascribed to the structural changes as a result of the release of guest molecules. Both the Dy-O distances and the dihedral angle between the Dy2O2 and phenyl planes changed greatly upon the loss of guest molecules, which further induces distinct magnetic relaxation behavior between 1 and 1a. To the best of our knowledge, complex 1 represents a rare example of the 2D dysprosium layer structure that possesses guest-dependent magnetic relaxation.

elements.content: In summary, we have reported the synthesis and structural characterization of a novel 2D dysprosium complex 1 constructed from a new multidentate PNO-containing ligand. Complex 1 exhibits temperature- and frequency-dependent ac signals under a zero dc field with an effective anisotropy barrier of 33.6 K. Interestingly, complex 1 possesses reversible magnetic behavior upon adsorption and desorption of CH3OH and water guest molecules. Compared to 1, the desolvated sample 1a shows distinct temperature- and frequency-dependent signals under a zero dc field with an effective energy barrier of 42.0 K. Therefore, the desorption and adsorption of guest CH3OH and water molecules can be conveniently used to mediate the magnetic properties of 1 and its desolvated form. Complex 1 represents one of the very few lanthanide–organic frameworks that display rather rare, reversible, guest-dependent magnetic behavior, providing a good opportunity for exploring the tuning effect of guest molecules on the slow magnetic relaxation of lanthanide-based magnetic systems.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have reported the synthesis and structural characterization of a novel 2D dysprosium complex 1 constructed from a new multidentate PNO-containing ligand. Complex 1 exhibits temperature- and frequency-dependent ac signals under a zero dc field with an effective anisotropy barrier of 33.6 K. Interestingly, complex 1 possesses reversible magnetic behavior upon adsorption and desorption of CH3OH and water guest molecules. Compared to 1, the desolvated sample 1a shows distinct temperature- and frequency-dependent signals under a zero dc field with an effective energy barrier of 42.0 K. Therefore, the desorption and adsorption of guest CH3OH and water molecules can be conveniently used to mediate the magnetic properties of 1 and its desolvated form. Complex 1 represents one of the very few lanthanide-organic frameworks that display rather rare, reversible, guest-dependent magnetic behavior, providing a good opportunity for exploring the tuning effect of guest molecules on the slow magnetic relaxation of lanthanide-based magnetic systems.

H2L (0.05 mmol, 0.0143 g) was dissolved in a mixture solvent of methanol (CH3OH; 1 mL) and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF; 0.75 mL). A methanolic solution of sodium hydroxide (NaOH; 1 mL, 50 mmol L–1) was then added to the mixture, affording a red solution. After stirring for 5 min, Dy­(OOCCH3)3·4H2O (0.05 mmol, 0.0206 g) was added, upon which the color of the solution immediately changed to yellow. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for another 10 min. After filtration, the filtrate was transferred to a test tube and layered with 2 mL of CH3OH. Block yellow crystals appeared in 1 week. Yield: 23.4 mg (74.6% based on the metal salt). Elem anal. Calcd for DyC19.5H27.5N3.5O9.5: C, 37.45; N, 7.84; H, 4.43. Found: C, 37.45; N, 7.89; H, 4.42. cln_elements.content:
dc magnetic susceptibility measurements have been performed on microcrystalline samples of 1 in the temperature range of 2–300 K at 1 kOe. As shown in , at room temperature, the observed χM T value of 29.04 cm3 mol–1 K is slightly larger than the expected value (28.34 cm3 mol–1 K) for two uncoupled Dy3+ ions with the ground state 6H15/2 and g = 4/3. The χM T value gradually decreases with a lowering of the temperature from 300 to 80 K, after which it decreases even more rapidly to reach 5.39 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. Thermal evolution of the magnetic susceptibility of 1 may be ascribed to the progressive depopulation of the excited-state m J sublevels of Dy3+ ions and/or the very strong antiferromagnetic interactions between Dy3+ ions within the dinuclear core. The field dependence of magnetization of 1 was investigated in the range of 0–50 kOe at 2, 3, 5, 8, and 10 K, respectively (). A rapid increase of the magnetization is observed at low magnetic fields, followed by a linear increase to 13.1 Nβ at 2 K. The nonsaturation of magnetization at 50 kOe and the nonsuperposition of the M versus H/T plots suggest the presence of a significant magnetic anisotropy and/or low-lying excited states in 1.

Thermal Stability and Reversibility of Dehydration of Compound <bold>1</bold>

To investigate the thermal stability of compound 1 and further affirm the exact molecular formula of the compound, TGA was performed in the temperature range of 35–800 °C under a synthetic air atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C min–1. The TGA curve of 1 exhibits three main steps of weight loss between room temperature and about 600 °C (Figure S9). The initial weight loss of 13.0% below 100 °C corresponds to the release of one interstitial water molecule as well as two CH3OH solvent molecules (calcd 13.1%). The weight loss of 5.9% in the temperature range of 100–180 °C stems from the release of one lattice DMF molecule (calcd 5.8%). Above 200 °C, the mass sharply decreases, which is assigned to thermal decomposition of the L2– ligand, leaving a residue of Dy2O3 with a final weight of 29.7% (calcd 29.8%).

It is interesting to note that when we very gently heat the sample of 1 at 35 °C under vacuum for 6 h or expose it to air for 1 month at room temperature, a dehydrated phase with the formula of [Dy­(L)­(OOCCH3)]·0.5DMF (1a) can be obtained. The thermal stability of 1a was also explored by TGA analysis, which revealed no weight loss below 100 °C (i.e., the absence of CH3OH and water guest molecules) but two weight loss steps at higher temperatures (Figure S9). The first weight loss of 6.9% below 180 °C, consistent with the calculated value of 6.7%, corresponds to the release of half of an interstitial DMF molecule. The second weight loss occurs in the temperature range of 200–700 °C and can be attributed to decomposition of the L2– ligand, giving rise to a residue of Dy2O3 with a final weight of 34.1% (calcd 34.3%). In the XRD pattern of 1a, the peaks at around 10° shift to a higher 2θ range compared to those of the as-synthesized 1, and a new sharp peak appears at ca. 12°, indicating structural transformation to lower symmetry upon the release of water and CH3OH molecules ().

Magnetic Behavior of Complex <bold>1a</bold>

To study the effect of desolvation on the magnetic properties, we measured the magnetic susceptibility of 1a in the temperature range of 2–300 K. As shown in , the experimental χM T value of 27.81 cm3 mol–1 K obtained at room temperature is slightly smaller than the excepted value (28.34 cm3 mol–1 K) for two uncoupled dysprosium ions in the ground state 6H15/2 with g = 4/3. The χM T value decreases slowly upon a decrease in the temperature from 300 to 100 K, after which it decreases more rapidly to reach 10.24 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. Thermal evolution of the magnetic susceptibility of 1a is similar to that of 1, which is attributed to depopulation of the Stark sublevels and/or interdimer antiferromagnetic interactions. The lack of a superposition of the M–H/T data on a single master curve and the low magnetization of 12.10 Nβ also suggest the presence of a significant magnetic anisotropy and/or low-lying excited states ().

Thermal evolution of the magnetic susceptibility of 1 may be ascribed to the progressive depopulation of the excited-state m  J  sublevels of Dy3+ ions and/or the very strong antiferromagnetic interactions between Dy3+ ions within the dinuclear core. The field dependence of magnetization of 1 was investigated in the range of 0-50 kOe at 2, 3, 5, 8, and 10 K, respectively (). A rapid increase of the magnetization is observed at low magnetic fields, followed by a linear increase to 13.1 Nβ at 2 K. The nonsaturation of magnetization at 50 kOe and the nonsuperposition of the M versus H/T plots suggest the presence of a significant magnetic anisotropy and/or low-lying excited states in 1.

Thermal Stability and Reversibility of Dehydration of Compound 1 

To investigate the thermal stability of compound 1 and further affirm the exact molecular formula of the compound, TGA was performed in the temperature range of 35-800 °C under a synthetic air atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C min-1. The TGA curve of 1 exhibits three main steps of weight loss between room temperature and about 600 °C (Figure S9). The weight loss of 5.9% in the temperature range of 100-180 °C stems from the release of one lattice DMF molecule (calcd 5.8%). Above 200 °C, the mass sharply decreases, which is assigned to thermal decomposition of the L2- ligand, leaving a residue of Dy2O3 with a final weight of 29.7% (calcd 29.8%).

It is interesting to note that when we very gently heat the sample of 1 at 35 °C under vacuum for 6 h or expose it to air for 1 month at room temperature, a dehydrated phase with the formula of [Dy(L)(OOCCH3)]⋅0.5DMF (1a) can be obtained. The thermal stability of 1a was also explored by TGA analysis, which revealed no weight loss below 100 °C (i.e., the absence of CH3OH and water guest molecules) but two weight loss steps at higher temperatures (Figure S9). The first weight loss of 6.9% below 180 °C, consistent with the calculated value of 6.7%, corresponds to the release of half of an interstitial DMF molecule. The second weight loss occurs in the temperature range of 200-700 °C and can be attributed to decomposition of the L2- ligand, giving rise to a residue of Dy2O3 with a final weight of 34.1% (calcd 34.3%). In the XRD pattern of 1a, the peaks at around 10° shift to a higher 2θ range compared to those of the as-synthesized 1, and a new sharp peak appears at ca. 12°, indicating structural transformation to lower symmetry upon the release of water and CH3OH molecules ().

Magnetic Behavior of Complex 1a 

To study the effect of desolvation on the magnetic properties, we measured the magnetic susceptibility of 1a in the temperature range of 2-300 K. As shown in , the experimental χM T value of 27.81 cm3 mol-1 K obtained at room temperature is slightly smaller than the excepted value (28.34 cm3 mol-1 K) for two uncoupled dysprosium ions in the ground state 6H15/2 with g = 4/3. The χM T value decreases slowly upon a decrease in the temperature from 300 to 100 K, after which it decreases more rapidly to reach 10.24 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. Thermal evolution of the magnetic susceptibility of 1a is similar to that of 1, which is attributed to depopulation of the Stark sublevels and/or interdimer antiferromagnetic interactions. The lack of a superposition of the M-H/T data on a single master curve and the low magnetization of 12.10 Nβ also suggest the presence of a significant magnetic anisotropy and/or low-lying excited states ().
